Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the application of Forest Reclamation Approach techniques on surface mined land in East Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Surface mining is an intense and ecologically destructive process that involves the removal of native vegetation (e.g., diverse and productive forests) and soil to prepare for resource extraction. Surface mining for coal is commonly conducted in Appalachia in the United States, and also in parts of New South Wales and Queensland in Australia. Because of the impacts of the mining process on native ecosystems, restoration is critical on mined sites. In Australia, similar to in Appalachia, many mined sites are reclaimed to grassland systems, which provide less ecological benefit than native forests. Therefore, developing reclamation techniques that can successfully restore native forests to mined sites should be a priority. The Forest Reclamation Approach (FRA) is a set of guidelines developed in Appalachia for establishing native forest systems on mined sites. However, it has not yet been tested for transferability outside the U.S. This project will assess the potential for FRA techniques to successfully restore native forests in Australia. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Paul Bertsch, a noted soil scientist with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Australia.

This project will take place on the Wambo Surface Mine in New South Wales, Australia. Experimental reclamation plots have been constructed with spoil type and compaction mitigation technique as treatments. Studies in Appalachia have shown that weathered minesoils provide a better growth medium than unweathered minesoils. Studies in Appalachia have found that native trees grow poorly in heavily compacted minesoils; therefore, already compacted soils must be ripped to improve tree growth potential. Alternatively, minesoils can be placed using minimal compaction techniques (e.g., loose-dumping) at the beginning. Five species of native trees were planted directly into the experimental plots in Fall 2013. This project will assess first-year survival and growth of these trees, as well as natural vegetative colonization and soil microbial development. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was initiated to develop sensitive molecular techniques for detecting and quantifying human enteric RNA viruses in wastewater. Human enteric viruses cause gastroenteritis—diarrhea and vomiting. Enteric viruses are highly infectious and spread rapidly through human populations, especially in densely populated areas. These viruses replicate in intestinal cells and are shed with feces. Thus, municipal wastewater often contains very high numbers of enteric viruses.

Conventionally, bacterial benchmarks are used for monitoring quality of treated wastewater. Thus, if indicator bacteria are detected below threshold values, wastewater is considered sufficiently well-treated to be discharged into surface waters. However, recent research demonstrates that bacterial indicators do not accurately predict treated wastewater quality with respect to enteric viruses. For example, treated wastewater can have very low bacterial counts but still have potentially infectious numbers of enteric viruses.

We successfully developed quantitative methods for detecting three RNA enteric viruses from wastewater: aichivirus, astrovirus, and sapovirus. As a next step, we will utilize our method to quantify these viruses before and after wastewater treatment and calculate the average reduction in virus counts during wastewater treatment. Very little is known about persistence of these viruses through wastewater treatment. Thus, our project represents one of very few studies contributing to closing this knowledge gap.

Our project will contribute valuable information regarding the behavior of viruses during wastewater treatment. Improved understanding of virus persistence in treated wastewater will permit the development of improved procedures for wastewater treatment, as well as improved regulations for monitoring treated wastewater quality. Improvements in wastewater treatment methods and monitoring will lead in turn to improvements in water quality and water resource conservation in urban areas. As climate change and urbanization progress, high quality water resources will only become more valuable. This research will help safeguard these urban water resources, improving our ability to provide high quality water into the future.
